Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Safety in Dubai is truly unmatched, and it’s one of the city’s most remarkable qualities. Even at 2 a.m.,,the streets are alive as if the evening has just begun..Families with young children, women walking alone or in groups, and friends hanging out without a single worry. There’s a deep sense of security and peace that allows residents and tourists to enjoy life freely at any hour. The presence of a strong legal system, advanced surveillance, and a zero-tolerance approach to crime plays a big role in this environment. Public spaces are clean, well-lit, and constantly monitored, making people feel safe whether they’re dining out late, taking a walk by the beach, or shopping at 24-hour outlets.In a world where safety is often a luxury, Dubai has made it the norm and that’s what truly sets it apart…..

نقوم بنشر 50+ وظيفة يومياً يرجى النقر على إعجاب أو تعليق ليصلكم كل جديد التفاصيل ضمن موقعنا الالكتروني:  Comprehensive Guide: Names of Oil Companies in the UAE and Their Official Email Addresses  The United Arab Emirates (UAE) stands as one of the world’s leading oil and gas producers, thanks to the presence of many prominent companies in this vital sector. For job seekers looking to break into the industry, knowing the names of oil companies in the UAE and the official email addresses of oil companies in […]  The United Arab Emirates (UAE) stands as one of the world’s leading oil and gas producers, thanks to the presence of many prominent companies in this vital sector. For job seekers looking to break into the industry, knowing the names of oil companies in the UAE and the official email addresses of oil companies in the UAE is crucial for sending resumes and applying for available positions. In this article, we provide a detailed directory of the most important companies, including their contact details and useful information.Why Knowing the Names of Oil Companies in the UAE MattersThe oil and gas sector is a cornerstone of the UAE economy, contributing a significant share of the country’s GDP. The names of oil companies in the UAE include major national firms like Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC), Dubai-based ENOC, and several international giants such as Schlumberger and Halliburton, which offer services across the region.These companies provide a wide range of job opportunities, whether in field operations, refineries, administration, or research centers. By having access to the official email addresses of oil companies in the UAE, job seekers can connect directly with human resources or recruitment departments, speeding up the job search process and increasing their chances of landing an interview.List of Major Oil Companies in the UAE and Their Official Email Addresses1️⃣ Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC)Email: adnoc@adnoc.comWebsite: www.adnoc.aeADNOC is one of the largest national oil companies globally, managing exploration, refining, and distribution operations in Abu Dhabi.2️⃣ Emirates National Oil Company (ENOC)Email: ahmed.alaa@enoc.comWebsite: www.enoc.comENOC is a government-owned company engaged in oil, gas, and energy services with a strong presence in Dubai and the northern Emirates.3️⃣ Emarat (Emirates General Petroleum Corporation)Email: info@emarat.aeWebsite: www.emarat.aeEmarat focuses on fuel distribution and operates a network of service stations across Dubai and the northern regions.4️⃣ Abu Dhabi Gas Industries Limited (GASCO)Email: info@gasco.aeWebsite: www.gasco.aeGASCO specializes in natural gas processing and transportation.5️⃣ Abu Dhabi Oil Refining Company (Takreer)Email: publicrelations@takreer.comWebsite: www.takreer.comTak

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Safety in Dubai is truly unmatched, and it’s one of the city’s most remarkable qualities. Even at 2 a.m.,,the streets are alive as if the evening has just begun..Families with young children, women walking alone or in groups, and friends hanging out without a single worry. There’s a deep sense of security and peace that allows residents and tourists to enjoy life freely at any hour. The presence of a strong legal system, advanced surveillance, and a zero-tolerance approach to crime plays a big role in this environment. Public spaces are clean, well-lit, and constantly monitored, making people feel safe whether they’re dining out late, taking a walk by the beach, or shopping at 24-hour outlets.In a world where safety is often a luxury, Dubai has made it the norm and that’s what truly sets it apart…..

نقوم بنشر 50+ وظيفة يومياً يرجى النقر على إعجاب أو تعليق ليصلكم كل جديد التفاصيل ضمن موقعنا الالكتروني:  Comprehensive Guide: Names of Oil Companies in the UAE and Their Official Email Addresses  The United Arab Emirates (UAE) stands as one of the world’s leading oil and gas producers, thanks to the presence of many prominent companies in this vital sector. For job seekers looking to break into the industry, knowing the names of oil companies in the UAE and the official email addresses of oil companies in […]  The United Arab Emirates (UAE) stands as one of the world’s leading oil and gas producers, thanks to the presence of many prominent companies in this vital sector. For job seekers looking to break into the industry, knowing the names of oil companies in the UAE and the official email addresses of oil companies in the UAE is crucial for sending resumes and applying for available positions. In this article, we provide a detailed directory of the most important companies, including their contact details and useful information.Why Knowing the Names of Oil Companies in the UAE MattersThe oil and gas sector is a cornerstone of the UAE economy, contributing a significant share of the country’s GDP. The names of oil companies in the UAE include major national firms like Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC), Dubai-based ENOC, and several international giants such as Schlumberger and Halliburton, which offer services across the region.These companies provide a wide range of job opportunities, whether in field operations, refineries, administration, or research centers. By having access to the official email addresses of oil companies in the UAE, job seekers can connect directly with human resources or recruitment departments, speeding up the job search process and increasing their chances of landing an interview.List of Major Oil Companies in the UAE and Their Official Email Addresses1️⃣ Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC)Email: adnoc@adnoc.comWebsite: www.adnoc.aeADNOC is one of the largest national oil companies globally, managing exploration, refining, and distribution operations in Abu Dhabi.2️⃣ Emirates National Oil Company (ENOC)Email: ahmed.alaa@enoc.comWebsite: www.enoc.comENOC is a government-owned company engaged in oil, gas, and energy services with a strong presence in Dubai and the northern Emirates.3️⃣ Emarat (Emirates General Petroleum Corporation)Email: info@emarat.aeWebsite: www.emarat.aeEmarat focuses on fuel distribution and operates a network of service stations across Dubai and the northern regions.4️⃣ Abu Dhabi Gas Industries Limited (GASCO)Email: info@gasco.aeWebsite: www.gasco.aeGASCO specializes in natural gas processing and transportation.5️⃣ Abu Dhabi Oil Refining Company (Takreer)Email: publicrelations@takreer.comWebsite: www.takreer.comTak

Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.—its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a “Trump 2.0” administration, the UAE—particularly Dubai—is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profound—particularly for Dubai’s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubai’s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

There’s a deep sense of security and peace that allows residents and tourists to enjoy life freely at any hour. The presence of a strong legal system, advanced surveillance, and a zero-tolerance approach to crime plays a big role in this environment. For job seekers looking to break into the industry, knowing the names of oil companies in the UAE and the official email addresses of oil companies in […]  The United Arab Emirates (UAE) stands as one of the world’s leading oil and gas producers, thanks to the presence of many prominent companies in this vital sector. For job seekers looking to break into the industry, knowing the names of oil companies in the UAE and the official email addresses of oil companies in the UAE is crucial for sending resumes and applying for available positions. In this article, we provide a detailed directory of the most important companies, including their contact details and useful information.Why Knowing the Names of Oil Companies in the UAE MattersThe oil and gas sector is a cornerstone of the UAE economy, contributing a significant share of the country’s GDP. The names of oil companies in the UAE include major national firms like Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC), Dubai-based ENOC, and several international giants such as Schlumberger and Halliburton, which offer services across the region.These companies provide a wide range of job opportunities, whether in field operations, refineries, administration, or research centers. By having access to the official email addresses of oil companies in the UAE, job seekers can connect directly with human resources or recruitment departments, speeding up the job search process and increasing their chances of landing an interview.List of Major Oil Companies in the UAE and Their Official Email Addresses1️⃣ Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC)Email: adnoc@adnoc.comWebsite: www.adnoc.aeADNOC is one of the largest national oil companies globally, managing exploration, refining, and distribution operations in Abu Dhabi.2️⃣ Emirates National Oil Company (ENOC)Email: ahmed.alaa@enoc.comWebsite: www.enoc.comENOC is a government-owned company engaged in oil, gas, and energy services with a strong presence in Dubai and the northern Emirates.3️⃣ Emarat (Emirates General Petroleum Corporation)Email: info@emarat.aeWebsite: www.emarat.aeEmarat focuses on fuel distribution and operates a network of service stations across Dubai and the northern regions.4️⃣ Abu Dhabi Gas Industries Limited (GASCO)Email: info@gasco.aeWebsite: www.gasco.aeGASCO specializes in natural gas processing and transportation.5️⃣ Abu Dhabi Oil Refining Company (Takreer)Email: publicrelations@takreer.comWebsite: www.takreer.comTak

Inside the E-Commerce Boom in the UAE: Opportunities, Challenges, and the Road AheadBy Nigar ValiyevaThe UAE’s e-commerce sector is booming—and I’ve lived it from the inside.From founding multiple startups in Dubai to navigating growth and competition, I’ve seen firsthand what makes this market so powerful—and where the real challenges lie.In this article, I share key insights, lessons for entrepreneurs, and what the road ahead looks like for digital commerce in the region.Read, comment, and share if you believe in the power of entrepreneurship.hashtag#UAE hashtag#Ecommerce hashtag#Startups hashtag#DigitalBusiness hashtag#WomenInBusiness hashtag#Entrepreneurship hashtag#DubaiThe UAE has quickly become a leading e-commerce hub in the Middle East, thanks to technological advancements, government initiatives, and a tech-savvy population. With platforms like Noon and Amazon becoming household names, the market has seen exponential growth, especially in sectors like fashion, electronics, and food delivery.Opportunities for EntrepreneursThe UAE offers an ideal environment for e-commerce startups, with attractive tax policies and a business-friendly infrastructure. Free zones like Dubai Internet City and Jebel Ali are magnets for digital entrepreneurs. Women-led startups are also reshaping the industry, with innovative businesses across fashion, beauty, and digital services.Challenges for E-Commerce FoundersWhile the opportunities are abundant, challenges persist. Global players like Amazon and Noon dominate, making it tough for smaller players. Additionally, high digital marketing costs, brand visibility issues, and cultural expectations are barriers to success. Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.—its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a “Trump 2.0” administration, the UAE—particularly Dubai—is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profound—particularly for Dubai’s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubai’s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Remember The Devil Wears Prada? Dubai is the 2.0 version. Welcome to modern slavery in designer clothes. Since being based here as a freelancer, I've had many people reach out with job offers and opportunities. While this city is known for its glitz and glamour, there are some hard lessons I’ve learned that I think are important for anyone considering a move here.- While Dubai offers perks like zero income tax and attractive salaries, there are some important realities to consider:-Job security can be shaky – you can be terminated without any explanation during your probation period.-Your immigration status is tied to your employment, and unless you have a golden visa, your residency can be at risk if your job ends suddenly.-The cost of living is high, and even with a half a million salary in your country per month, it might not be enough to cover everything.-Accommodation is super expensive, and it’s rarely paid monthly. In most cases, you’ll be expected to pay rent in 1 or worse case 2 instalments – or best, 4 months upfront – plus all your utility bills on top (electricity, water, air con internet, tv etc.). Your employer will not necessarily pay for hotel costs pending you find an accommodation. -Work culture here can be intense – if your boss works 24/7, so will you, as well as other dodgy work conditions that you cannot fight and under constant pressure of potential termination and deportation.-Forget employment rights. Forget human rights.The city might shine, but not everything that glitters is gold. Be informed, be cautious, and ask the right questions before saying yes.hashtag#Dubai hashtag#FreelancerLife hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobOpportunities hashtag#LivingInDubai hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#Immigration hashtag#GoldenVisa hashtag#RealityCheck hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#ExpatLife hashtag#CostOfLiving hashtag#RentalReality hashtag#Utilities hashtag#HardTruths hashtag#ModernSlavery

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.—its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a “Trump 2.0” administration, the UAE—particularly Dubai—is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profound—particularly for Dubai’s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubai’s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Inside the E-Commerce Boom in the UAE: Opportunities, Challenges, and the Road AheadBy Nigar ValiyevaThe UAE’s e-commerce sector is booming—and I’ve lived it from the inside.From founding multiple startups in Dubai to navigating growth and competition, I’ve seen firsthand what makes this market so powerful—and where the real challenges lie.In this article, I share key insights, lessons for entrepreneurs, and what the road ahead looks like for digital commerce in the region.Read, comment, and share if you believe in the power of entrepreneurship.hashtag#UAE hashtag#Ecommerce hashtag#Startups hashtag#DigitalBusiness hashtag#WomenInBusiness hashtag#Entrepreneurship hashtag#DubaiThe UAE has quickly become a leading e-commerce hub in the Middle East, thanks to technological advancements, government initiatives, and a tech-savvy population. With platforms like Noon and Amazon becoming household names, the market has seen exponential growth, especially in sectors like fashion, electronics, and food delivery.Opportunities for EntrepreneursThe UAE offers an ideal environment for e-commerce startups, with attractive tax policies and a business-friendly infrastructure. Free zones like Dubai Internet City and Jebel Ali are magnets for digital entrepreneurs. Women-led startups are also reshaping the industry, with innovative businesses across fashion, beauty, and digital services.Challenges for E-Commerce FoundersWhile the opportunities are abundant, challenges persist. Global players like Amazon and Noon dominate, making it tough for smaller players. Additionally, high digital marketing costs, brand visibility issues, and cultural expectations are barriers to success. Businesses must focus on trust, quality, and innovation to stay competitive.Key Takeaways •	Customer Experience is King: Simplified, fast service builds loyalty. •	Niche Wins: Unique positioning helps small brands stand out. •	Consistency & Adaptability: Be ready to pivot based on data and trends.Looking AheadThe future of UAE’s e-commerce will be shaped by technology—AI, AR, cross-border selling, and fintech integration. With continued government support and a strong entrepreneurial spirit, the UAE will remain at the forefront of the Middle East’s e-commerce revolution.⸻Nigar ValiyevaE-commerce & Events Entrepreneur | Advocate for Women in BusinessFounder, Dubai Startups: WooWDeal Trading FZE, Shop CartTrading FZE, Bakilili Commercial Broker LLC, Premium Shishas Management LLC

Remember The Devil Wears Prada? Dubai is the 2.0 version. Welcome to modern slavery in designer clothes. Since being based here as a freelancer, I've had many people reach out with job offers and opportunities. While this city is known for its glitz and glamour, there are some hard lessons I’ve learned that I think are important for anyone considering a move here.- While Dubai offers perks like zero income tax and attractive salaries, there are some important realities to consider:-Job security can be shaky – you can be terminated without any explanation during your probation period.-Your immigration status is tied to your employment, and unless you have a golden visa, your residency can be at risk if your job ends suddenly.-The cost of living is high, and even with a half a million salary in your country per month, it might not be enough to cover everything.-Accommodation is super expensive, and it’s rarely paid monthly. In most cases, you’ll be expected to pay rent in 1 or worse case 2 instalments – or best, 4 months upfront – plus all your utility bills on top (electricity, water, air con internet, tv etc.). Your employer will not necessarily pay for hotel costs pending you find an accommodation. -Work culture here can be intense – if your boss works 24/7, so will you, as well as other dodgy work conditions that you cannot fight and under constant pressure of potential termination and deportation.-Forget employment rights. Forget human rights.The city might shine, but not everything that glitters is gold. Be informed, be cautious, and ask the right questions before saying yes.hashtag#Dubai hashtag#FreelancerLife hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobOpportunities hashtag#LivingInDubai hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#Immigration hashtag#GoldenVisa hashtag#RealityCheck hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#ExpatLife hashtag#CostOfLiving hashtag#RentalReality hashtag#Utilities hashtag#HardTruths hashtag#ModernSlavery

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

For job seekers looking to break into the industry, knowing the names of oil companies in the UAE and the official email addresses of oil companies in […]  The United Arab Emirates (UAE) stands as one of the world’s leading oil and gas producers, thanks to the presence of many prominent companies in this vital sector. For job seekers looking to break into the industry, knowing the names of oil companies in the UAE and the official email addresses of oil companies in the UAE is crucial for sending resumes and applying for available positions. In this article, we provide a detailed directory of the most important companies, including their contact details and useful information.Why Knowing the Names of Oil Companies in the UAE MattersThe oil and gas sector is a cornerstone of the UAE economy, contributing a significant share of the country’s GDP. The names of oil companies in the UAE include major national firms like Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC), Dubai-based ENOC, and several international giants such as Schlumberger and Halliburton, which offer services across the region.These companies provide a wide range of job opportunities, whether in field operations, refineries, administration, or research centers. By having access to the official email addresses of oil companies in the UAE, job seekers can connect directly with human resources or recruitment departments, speeding up the job search process and increasing their chances of landing an interview.List of Major Oil Companies in the UAE and Their Official Email Addresses1️⃣ Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC)Email: adnoc@adnoc.comWebsite: www.adnoc.aeADNOC is one of the largest national oil companies globally, managing exploration, refining, and distribution operations in Abu Dhabi.2️⃣ Emirates National Oil Company (ENOC)Email: ahmed.alaa@enoc.comWebsite: www.enoc.comENOC is a government-owned company engaged in oil, gas, and energy services with a strong presence in Dubai and the northern Emirates.3️⃣ Emarat (Emirates General Petroleum Corporation)Email: info@emarat.aeWebsite: www.emarat.aeEmarat focuses on fuel distribution and operates a network of service stations across Dubai and the northern regions.4️⃣ Abu Dhabi Gas Industries Limited (GASCO)Email: info@gasco.aeWebsite: www.gasco.aeGASCO specializes in natural gas processing and transportation.5️⃣ Abu Dhabi Oil Refining Company (Takreer)Email: publicrelations@takreer.comWebsite: www.takreer.comTak

Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.—its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a “Trump 2.0” administration, the UAE—particularly Dubai—is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profound—particularly for Dubai’s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubai’s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Inside the E-Commerce Boom in the UAE: Opportunities, Challenges, and the Road AheadBy Nigar ValiyevaThe UAE’s e-commerce sector is booming—and I’ve lived it from the inside.From founding multiple startups in Dubai to navigating growth and competition, I’ve seen firsthand what makes this market so powerful—and where the real challenges lie.In this article, I share key insights, lessons for entrepreneurs, and what the road ahead looks like for digital commerce in the region.Read, comment, and share if you believe in the power of entrepreneurship.hashtag#UAE hashtag#Ecommerce hashtag#Startups hashtag#DigitalBusiness hashtag#WomenInBusiness hashtag#Entrepreneurship hashtag#DubaiThe UAE has quickly become a leading e-commerce hub in the Middle East, thanks to technological advancements, government initiatives, and a tech-savvy population. With platforms like Noon and Amazon becoming household names, the market has seen exponential growth, especially in sectors like fashion, electronics, and food delivery.Opportunities for EntrepreneursThe UAE offers an ideal environment for e-commerce startups, with attractive tax policies and a business-friendly infrastructure. Free zones like Dubai Internet City and Jebel Ali are magnets for digital entrepreneurs. Women-led startups are also reshaping the industry, with innovative businesses across fashion, beauty, and digital services.Challenges for E-Commerce FoundersWhile the opportunities are abundant, challenges persist. Global players like Amazon and Noon dominate, making it tough for smaller players. Additionally, high digital marketing costs, brand visibility issues, and cultural expectations are barriers to success. Businesses must focus on trust, quality, and innovation to stay competitive.Key Takeaways •	Customer Experience is King: Simplified, fast service builds loyalty. •	Niche Wins: Unique positioning helps small brands stand out. •	Consistency & Adaptability: Be ready to pivot based on data and trends.Looking AheadThe future of UAE’s e-commerce will be shaped by technology—AI, AR, cross-border selling, and fintech integration. With continued government support and a strong entrepreneurial spirit, the UAE will remain at the forefront of the Middle East’s e-commerce revolution.⸻Nigar ValiyevaE-commerce & Events Entrepreneur | Advocate for Women in BusinessFounder, Dubai Startups: WooWDeal Trading FZE, Shop CartTrading FZE, Bakilili Commercial Broker LLC, Premium Shishas Management LLC

Recently, my team noticed a guest’s sunglasses and laptop in the room and immediately took action. Without being asked, they placed a premium microfiber cloth beside the devices, ensuring a pristine screen at all times. But he didn’t stop there—He organized the guest’s cables with an elegant cable manager, leaving everything effortlessly tidy. A handwritten note completed the gesture.Later, I had the pleasure of speaking with the guest during his departure. He was genuinely moved by the initiative, saying, "I was amazed that your team thought this way—no one has ever taken such care with the little things. It made all the difference."This is the essence of Conrad Dubai: not just meeting expectations, but exceeding them with intuitive, personalized service. Remember The Devil Wears Prada? Dubai is the 2.0 version. Welcome to modern slavery in designer clothes. Since being based here as a freelancer, I've had many people reach out with job offers and opportunities. While this city is known for its glitz and glamour, there are some hard lessons I’ve learned that I think are important for anyone considering a move here.- While Dubai offers perks like zero income tax and attractive salaries, there are some important realities to consider:-Job security can be shaky – you can be terminated without any explanation during your probation period.-Your immigration status is tied to your employment, and unless you have a golden visa, your residency can be at risk if your job ends suddenly.-The cost of living is high, and even with a half a million salary in your country per month, it might not be enough to cover everything.-Accommodation is super expensive, and it’s rarely paid monthly. In most cases, you’ll be expected to pay rent in 1 or worse case 2 instalments – or best, 4 months upfront – plus all your utility bills on top (electricity, water, air con internet, tv etc.). Your employer will not necessarily pay for hotel costs pending you find an accommodation. -Work culture here can be intense – if your boss works 24/7, so will you, as well as other dodgy work conditions that you cannot fight and under constant pressure of potential termination and deportation.-Forget employment rights. Forget human rights.The city might shine, but not everything that glitters is gold. Be informed, be cautious, and ask the right questions before saying yes.hashtag#Dubai hashtag#FreelancerLife hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobOpportunities hashtag#LivingInDubai hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#Immigration hashtag#GoldenVisa hashtag#RealityCheck hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#ExpatLife hashtag#CostOfLiving hashtag#RentalReality hashtag#Utilities hashtag#HardTruths hashtag#ModernSlavery

The government is now clearly working within the framework of the Economic Modernization Vision, which is Jordan’s roadmap for achieving sustainable growth by focusing on key parts of the economy. In 2024, macroeconomic indicators showed stability. The economy grew by 2.5 per cent and inflation stayed low at 2.21 per cent. GDP per person reached 3,228 dinars. The budget deficit after aid remained low at 0.7 per cent of GDP. Foreign currency reserves were $22 billion in March 2025, enough to cover 8.5 months of imports. Foreign direct investment reached 1,122 million dinars. Imports totaled 1,623 million dinars, while exports were 703 million dinars.

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

For job seekers looking to break into the industry, knowing the names of oil companies in the UAE and the official email addresses of oil companies in the UAE is crucial for sending resumes and applying for available positions. Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.—its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a “Trump 2.0” administration, the UAE—particularly Dubai—is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profound—particularly for Dubai’s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubai’s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Inside the E-Commerce Boom in the UAE: Opportunities, Challenges, and the Road AheadBy Nigar ValiyevaThe UAE’s e-commerce sector is booming—and I’ve lived it from the inside.From founding multiple startups in Dubai to navigating growth and competition, I’ve seen firsthand what makes this market so powerful—and where the real challenges lie.In this article, I share key insights, lessons for entrepreneurs, and what the road ahead looks like for digital commerce in the region.Read, comment, and share if you believe in the power of entrepreneurship.hashtag#UAE hashtag#Ecommerce hashtag#Startups hashtag#DigitalBusiness hashtag#WomenInBusiness hashtag#Entrepreneurship hashtag#DubaiThe UAE has quickly become a leading e-commerce hub in the Middle East, thanks to technological advancements, government initiatives, and a tech-savvy population. With platforms like Noon and Amazon becoming household names, the market has seen exponential growth, especially in sectors like fashion, electronics, and food delivery.Opportunities for EntrepreneursThe UAE offers an ideal environment for e-commerce startups, with attractive tax policies and a business-friendly infrastructure. Free zones like Dubai Internet City and Jebel Ali are magnets for digital entrepreneurs. Women-led startups are also reshaping the industry, with innovative businesses across fashion, beauty, and digital services.Challenges for E-Commerce FoundersWhile the opportunities are abundant, challenges persist. Global players like Amazon and Noon dominate, making it tough for smaller players. Additionally, high digital marketing costs, brand visibility issues, and cultural expectations are barriers to success. Businesses must focus on trust, quality, and innovation to stay competitive.Key Takeaways •	Customer Experience is King: Simplified, fast service builds loyalty. •	Niche Wins: Unique positioning helps small brands stand out. •	Consistency & Adaptability: Be ready to pivot based on data and trends.Looking AheadThe future of UAE’s e-commerce will be shaped by technology—AI, AR, cross-border selling, and fintech integration. With continued government support and a strong entrepreneurial spirit, the UAE will remain at the forefront of the Middle East’s e-commerce revolution.⸻Nigar ValiyevaE-commerce & Events Entrepreneur | Advocate for Women in BusinessFounder, Dubai Startups: WooWDeal Trading FZE, Shop CartTrading FZE, Bakilili Commercial Broker LLC, Premium Shishas Management LLC

Remember The Devil Wears Prada? Dubai is the 2.0 version. Welcome to modern slavery in designer clothes. Since being based here as a freelancer, I've had many people reach out with job offers and opportunities. While this city is known for its glitz and glamour, there are some hard lessons I’ve learned that I think are important for anyone considering a move here.- While Dubai offers perks like zero income tax and attractive salaries, there are some important realities to consider:-Job security can be shaky – you can be terminated without any explanation during your probation period.-Your immigration status is tied to your employment, and unless you have a golden visa, your residency can be at risk if your job ends suddenly.-The cost of living is high, and even with a half a million salary in your country per month, it might not be enough to cover everything.-Accommodation is super expensive, and it’s rarely paid monthly. In most cases, you’ll be expected to pay rent in 1 or worse case 2 instalments – or best, 4 months upfront – plus all your utility bills on top (electricity, water, air con internet, tv etc.). Your employer will not necessarily pay for hotel costs pending you find an accommodation. -Work culture here can be intense – if your boss works 24/7, so will you, as well as other dodgy work conditions that you cannot fight and under constant pressure of potential termination and deportation.-Forget employment rights. Forget human rights.The city might shine, but not everything that glitters is gold. Be informed, be cautious, and ask the right questions before saying yes.hashtag#Dubai hashtag#FreelancerLife hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobOpportunities hashtag#LivingInDubai hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#Immigration hashtag#GoldenVisa hashtag#RealityCheck hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#ExpatLife hashtag#CostOfLiving hashtag#RentalReality hashtag#Utilities hashtag#HardTruths hashtag#ModernSlavery

Dubai Residency Visas Through Property Investment – 2025 UpdateWith rising interest in UAE residency options, here’s a quick overview of the three main property investment-linked visa categories available in Dubai:Option 1. 2-Year Investor Visa ➡️ Minimum Investment: AED 750,000 (ready or installment-based property) ➡️ Eligibility:50% of the construction completed or 50% of the property value paid ✅ Includes spouse and children 📌 Renewable every 2 yearsOption 2. 10-Year Golden Visa ➡️ Minimum Investment: AED 2,000,000 in one or more properties (ready or installment based) ➡️ Eligibility:Properties can be ready, off-plan, or mortgagedNOC required from bank if under mortgage ✅ Covers spouse, children, and parents 📌 Long-term stability, renewable every 10 yearsOption 3. 5-Year Retirement Visa ➡️ For individuals aged 55+ ➡️ Options:AED 1M in fully paid propertyAED 1M in a 3-year fixed depositCombination of income/savings totaling AED 1M ✅ Includes immediate family 📌 Great option for long-term retirees in DubaiFor more update please follow Renex Properties DubaiNabeel Tajik Hiba Akhtar

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Even at 2 a.m.,,the streets are alive as if the evening has just begun..Families with young children, women walking alone or in groups, and friends hanging out without a single worry. There’s a deep sense of security and peace that allows residents and tourists to enjoy life freely at any hour. The presence of a strong legal system, advanced surveillance, and a zero-tolerance approach to crime plays a big role in this environment. Public spaces are clean, well-lit, and constantly monitored, making people feel safe whether they’re dining out late, taking a walk by the beach, or shopping at 24-hour outlets.In a world where safety is often a luxury, Dubai has made it the norm and that’s what truly sets it apart…..

For job seekers looking to break into the industry, knowing the names of oil companies in the UAE and the official email addresses of oil companies in […]  The United Arab Emirates (UAE) stands as one of the world’s leading oil and gas producers, thanks to the presence of many prominent companies in this vital sector. For job seekers looking to break into the industry, knowing the names of oil companies in the UAE and the official email addresses of oil companies in the UAE is crucial for sending resumes and applying for available positions. In this article, we provide a detailed directory of the most important companies, including their contact details and useful information.Why Knowing the Names of Oil Companies in the UAE MattersThe oil and gas sector is a cornerstone of the UAE economy, contributing a significant share of the country’s GDP. The names of oil companies in the UAE include major national firms like Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC), Dubai-based ENOC, and several international giants such as Schlumberger and Halliburton, which offer services across the region.These companies provide a wide range of job opportunities, whether in field operations, refineries, administration, or research centers. By having access to the official email addresses of oil companies in the UAE, job seekers can connect directly with human resources or recruitment departments, speeding up the job search process and increasing their chances of landing an interview.List of Major Oil Companies in the UAE and Their Official Email Addresses1️⃣ Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC)Email: adnoc@adnoc.comWebsite: www.adnoc.aeADNOC is one of the largest national oil companies globally, managing exploration, refining, and distribution operations in Abu Dhabi.2️⃣ Emirates National Oil Company (ENOC)Email: ahmed.alaa@enoc.comWebsite: www.enoc.comENOC is a government-owned company engaged in oil, gas, and energy services with a strong presence in Dubai and the northern Emirates.3️⃣ Emarat (Emirates General Petroleum Corporation)Email: info@emarat.aeWebsite: www.emarat.aeEmarat focuses on fuel distribution and operates a network of service stations across Dubai and the northern regions.4️⃣ Abu Dhabi Gas Industries Limited (GASCO)Email: info@gasco.aeWebsite: www.gasco.aeGASCO specializes in natural gas processing and transportation.5️⃣ Abu Dhabi Oil Refining Company (Takreer)Email: publicrelations@takreer.comWebsite: www.takreer.comTak

Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.—its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a “Trump 2.0” administration, the UAE—particularly Dubai—is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profound—particularly for Dubai’s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubai’s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Inside the E-Commerce Boom in the UAE: Opportunities, Challenges, and the Road AheadBy Nigar ValiyevaThe UAE’s e-commerce sector is booming—and I’ve lived it from the inside.From founding multiple startups in Dubai to navigating growth and competition, I’ve seen firsthand what makes this market so powerful—and where the real challenges lie.In this article, I share key insights, lessons for entrepreneurs, and what the road ahead looks like for digital commerce in the region.Read, comment, and share if you believe in the power of entrepreneurship.hashtag#UAE hashtag#Ecommerce hashtag#Startups hashtag#DigitalBusiness hashtag#WomenInBusiness hashtag#Entrepreneurship hashtag#DubaiThe UAE has quickly become a leading e-commerce hub in the Middle East, thanks to technological advancements, government initiatives, and a tech-savvy population. With platforms like Noon and Amazon becoming household names, the market has seen exponential growth, especially in sectors like fashion, electronics, and food delivery.Opportunities for EntrepreneursThe UAE offers an ideal environment for e-commerce startups, with attractive tax policies and a business-friendly infrastructure. Free zones like Dubai Internet City and Jebel Ali are magnets for digital entrepreneurs. Women-led startups are also reshaping the industry, with innovative businesses across fashion, beauty, and digital services.Challenges for E-Commerce FoundersWhile the opportunities are abundant, challenges persist. Global players like Amazon and Noon dominate, making it tough for smaller players. Additionally, high digital marketing costs, brand visibility issues, and cultural expectations are barriers to success. Businesses must focus on trust, quality, and innovation to stay competitive.Key Takeaways •	Customer Experience is King: Simplified, fast service builds loyalty. •	Niche Wins: Unique positioning helps small brands stand out. •	Consistency & Adaptability: Be ready to pivot based on data and trends.Looking AheadThe future of UAE’s e-commerce will be shaped by technology—AI, AR, cross-border selling, and fintech integration. With continued government support and a strong entrepreneurial spirit, the UAE will remain at the forefront of the Middle East’s e-commerce revolution.⸻Nigar ValiyevaE-commerce & Events Entrepreneur | Advocate for Women in BusinessFounder, Dubai Startups: WooWDeal Trading FZE, Shop CartTrading FZE, Bakilili Commercial Broker LLC, Premium Shishas Management LLC

Without being asked, they placed a premium microfiber cloth beside the devices, ensuring a pristine screen at all times. But he didn’t stop there—He organized the guest’s cables with an elegant cable manager, leaving everything effortlessly tidy. He was genuinely moved by the initiative, saying, "I was amazed that your team thought this way—no one has ever taken such care with the little things. It made all the difference."This is the essence of Conrad Dubai: not just meeting expectations, but exceeding them with intuitive, personalized service. Remember The Devil Wears Prada? Dubai is the 2.0 version. Welcome to modern slavery in designer clothes. Since being based here as a freelancer, I've had many people reach out with job offers and opportunities. While this city is known for its glitz and glamour, there are some hard lessons I’ve learned that I think are important for anyone considering a move here.- While Dubai offers perks like zero income tax and attractive salaries, there are some important realities to consider:-Job security can be shaky – you can be terminated without any explanation during your probation period.-Your immigration status is tied to your employment, and unless you have a golden visa, your residency can be at risk if your job ends suddenly.-The cost of living is high, and even with a half a million salary in your country per month, it might not be enough to cover everything.-Accommodation is super expensive, and it’s rarely paid monthly. In most cases, you’ll be expected to pay rent in 1 or worse case 2 instalments – or best, 4 months upfront – plus all your utility bills on top (electricity, water, air con internet, tv etc.). Your employer will not necessarily pay for hotel costs pending you find an accommodation. -Work culture here can be intense – if your boss works 24/7, so will you, as well as other dodgy work conditions that you cannot fight and under constant pressure of potential termination and deportation.-Forget employment rights. Forget human rights.The city might shine, but not everything that glitters is gold. Be informed, be cautious, and ask the right questions before saying yes.hashtag#Dubai hashtag#FreelancerLife hashtag#CareerAdvice hashtag#JobOpportunities hashtag#LivingInDubai hashtag#LessonsLearned hashtag#WorkCulture hashtag#Immigration hashtag#GoldenVisa hashtag#RealityCheck hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#ExpatLife hashtag#CostOfLiving hashtag#RentalReality hashtag#Utilities hashtag#HardTruths hashtag#ModernSlavery

Dubai Residency Visas Through Property Investment – 2025 UpdateWith rising interest in UAE residency options, here’s a quick overview of the three main property investment-linked visa categories available in Dubai:Option 1. 2-Year Investor Visa ➡️ Minimum Investment: AED 750,000 (ready or installment-based property) ➡️ Eligibility:50% of the construction completed or 50% of the property value paid ✅ Includes spouse and children 📌 Renewable every 2 yearsOption 2. 10-Year Golden Visa ➡️ Minimum Investment: AED 2,000,000 in one or more properties (ready or installment based) ➡️ Eligibility:Properties can be ready, off-plan, or mortgagedNOC required from bank if under mortgage ✅ Covers spouse, children, and parents 📌 Long-term stability, renewable every 10 yearsOption 3. 5-Year Retirement Visa ➡️ For individuals aged 55+ ➡️ Options:AED 1M in fully paid propertyAED 1M in a 3-year fixed depositCombination of income/savings totaling AED 1M ✅ Includes immediate family 📌 Great option for long-term retirees in DubaiFor more update please follow Renex Properties DubaiNabeel Tajik Hiba Akhtar

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

For job seekers looking to break into the industry, knowing the names of oil companies in the UAE and the official email addresses of oil companies in the UAE is crucial for sending resumes and applying for available positions. In this article, we provide a detailed directory of the most important companies, including their contact details and useful information.Why Knowing the Names of Oil Companies in the UAE MattersThe oil and gas sector is a cornerstone of the UAE economy, contributing a significant share of the country’s GDP. The names of oil companies in the UAE include major national firms like Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC), Dubai-based ENOC, and several international giants such as Schlumberger and Halliburton, which offer services across the region.These companies provide a wide range of job opportunities, whether in field operations, refineries, administration, or research centers. Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.—its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a “Trump 2.0” administration, the UAE—particularly Dubai—is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profound—particularly for Dubai’s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubai’s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.

Inside the E-Commerce Boom in the UAE: Opportunities, Challenges, and the Road AheadBy Nigar ValiyevaThe UAE’s e-commerce sector is booming—and I’ve lived it from the inside.From founding multiple startups in Dubai to navigating growth and competition, I’ve seen firsthand what makes this market so powerful—and where the real challenges lie.In this article, I share key insights, lessons for entrepreneurs, and what the road ahead looks like for digital commerce in the region.Read, comment, and share if you believe in the power of entrepreneurship.hashtag#UAE hashtag#Ecommerce hashtag#Startups hashtag#DigitalBusiness hashtag#WomenInBusiness hashtag#Entrepreneurship hashtag#DubaiThe UAE has quickly become a leading e-commerce hub in the Middle East, thanks to technological advancements, government initiatives, and a tech-savvy population. With platforms like Noon and Amazon becoming household names, the market has seen exponential growth, especially in sectors like fashion, electronics, and food delivery.Opportunities for EntrepreneursThe UAE offers an ideal environment for e-commerce startups, with attractive tax policies and a business-friendly infrastructure. Free zones like Dubai Internet City and Jebel Ali are magnets for digital entrepreneurs. Women-led startups are also reshaping the industry, with innovative businesses across fashion, beauty, and digital services.Challenges for E-Commerce FoundersWhile the opportunities are abundant, challenges persist. Global players like Amazon and Noon dominate, making it tough for smaller players. Additionally, high digital marketing costs, brand visibility issues, and cultural expectations are barriers to success. Businesses must focus on trust, quality, and innovation to stay competitive.Key Takeaways •	Customer Experience is King: Simplified, fast service builds loyalty. •	Niche Wins: Unique positioning helps small brands stand out. •	Consistency & Adaptability: Be ready to pivot based on data and trends.Looking AheadThe future of UAE’s e-commerce will be shaped by technology—AI, AR, cross-border selling, and fintech integration. With continued government support and a strong entrepreneurial spirit, the UAE will remain at the forefront of the Middle East’s e-commerce revolution.⸻Nigar ValiyevaE-commerce & Events Entrepreneur | Advocate for Women in BusinessFounder, Dubai Startups: WooWDeal Trading FZE, Shop CartTrading FZE, Bakilili Commercial Broker LLC, Premium Shishas Management LLC

Remember The Devil Wears Prada? Dubai is the 2.0 version. Welcome to modern slavery in designer clothes. Since being based here as a freelancer, I've had many people reach out with job offers and opportunities. While this city is known for its glitz and glamour, there are some hard lessons I’ve learned that I think are important for anyone considering a move here.- While Dubai offers perks like zero income tax and attractive salaries, there are some important realities to consider:-Job security can be shaky – you can be terminated without any explanation during your probation period.-Your immigration status is tied to your employment, and unless you have a golden visa, your residency can be at risk if your job ends suddenly.-The cost of living is high, and even with a half a million salary in your country per month, it might not be enough to cover everything.-Accommodation is super expensive, and it’s rarely paid monthly. In most cases, you’ll be expected to pay rent in 1 or worse case 2 instalments – or best, 4 months upfront – plus all your utility bills on top (electricity, water, air con internet, tv etc.). Your employer will not necessarily pay for hotel costs pending you find an accommodation. -Work culture here can be intense – if your boss works 24/7, so will you, as well as other dodgy work conditions that you cannot fight and under constant pressure of potential termination and deportation.-Forget employment rights. Forget human rights.The city might shine, but not everything that glitters is gold. Dubai Residency Visas Through Property Investment – 2025 UpdateWith rising interest in UAE residency options, here’s a quick overview of the three main property investment-linked visa categories available in Dubai:Option 1. 2-Year Investor Visa ➡️ Minimum Investment: AED 750,000 (ready or installment-based property) ➡️ Eligibility:50% of the construction completed or 50% of the property value paid ✅ Includes spouse and children 📌 Renewable every 2 yearsOption 2. 10-Year Golden Visa ➡️ Minimum Investment: AED 2,000,000 in one or more properties (ready or installment based) ➡️ Eligibility:Properties can be ready, off-plan, or mortgagedNOC required from bank if under mortgage ✅ Covers spouse, children, and parents 📌 Long-term stability, renewable every 10 yearsOption 3. 5-Year Retirement Visa ➡️ For individuals aged 55+ ➡️ Options:AED 1M in fully paid propertyAED 1M in a 3-year fixed depositCombination of income/savings totaling AED 1M ✅ Includes immediate family 📌 Great option for long-term retirees in DubaiFor more update please follow Renex Properties DubaiNabeel Tajik Hiba Akhtar

The government is now clearly working within the framework of the Economic Modernization Vision, which is Jordan’s roadmap for achieving sustainable growth by focusing on key parts of the economy. In 2024, macroeconomic indicators showed stability. The economy grew by 2.5 per cent and inflation stayed low at 2.21 per cent. GDP per person reached 3,228 dinars. The budget deficit after aid remained low at 0.7 per cent of GDP. Foreign currency reserves were $22 billion in March 2025, enough to cover 8.5 months of imports. Foreign direct investment reached 1,122 million dinars. Imports totaled 1,623 million dinars, while exports were 703 million dinars.

Elissa Freiha is a trailblazing Emirati-Lebanese-American entrepreneur, investor, and women's rights activist who has empowered women in the Middle East's innovation and investment sectors. Elissa moved to Dubai when she was 23 years old and founded Womena in 2014 to empower female entrepreneurs through angel investment and education. Women's initial goal was to help women obtain early-stage venture capital. As Womena evolved into a storytelling platform that inspires change in 2018, Elissa shifted the company's focus to empowering women in the region. Womentum, founded in 2018 by Elissa and Womena, is a technology accelerator and documentary series that supports Middle Eastern female-led startups. This initiative, developed in collaboration with Standard Chartered, provides mentoring, financial support, and exposure to female entrepreneurs to close the gender gap in the technology sector. Elissa has served on the board of the Dubai Chamber of Digital Economy since 2021, helping to shape the region's digital landscape.If you want to be featured on Arab Icons and have your story inspire the Arab world, please contact us via WhatsApp at 00201151077931 or Englishlancer2016@gmail.com.hashtag#dubai hashtag#UAE

Safety in Dubai is truly unmatched, and it’s one of the city’s most remarkable qualities. Even at 2 a.m.,,the streets are alive as if the evening has just begun..Families with young children, women walking alone or in groups, and friends hanging out without a single worry. There’s a deep sense of security and peace that allows residents and tourists to enjoy life freely at any hour. The presence of a strong legal system, advanced surveillance, and a zero-tolerance approach to crime plays a big role in this environment. Public spaces are clean, well-lit, and constantly monitored, making people feel safe whether they’re dining out late, taking a walk by the beach, or shopping at 24-hour outlets.In a world where safety is often a luxury, Dubai has made it the norm and that’s what truly sets it apart…..

نقوم بنشر 50+ وظيفة يومياً يرجى النقر على إعجاب أو تعليق ليصلكم كل جديد التفاصيل ضمن موقعنا الالكتروني:  Comprehensive Guide: Names of Oil Companies in the UAE and Their Official Email Addresses  The United Arab Emirates (UAE) stands as one of the world’s leading oil and gas producers, thanks to the presence of many prominent companies in this vital sector. For job seekers looking to break into the industry, knowing the names of oil companies in the UAE and the official email addresses of oil companies in […]  The United Arab Emirates (UAE) stands as one of the world’s leading oil and gas producers, thanks to the presence of many prominent companies in this vital sector. For job seekers looking to break into the industry, knowing the names of oil companies in the UAE and the official email addresses of oil companies in the UAE is crucial for sending resumes and applying for available positions. In this article, we provide a detailed directory of the most important companies, including their contact details and useful information.Why Knowing the Names of Oil Companies in the UAE MattersThe oil and gas sector is a cornerstone of the UAE economy, contributing a significant share of the country’s GDP. The names of oil companies in the UAE include major national firms like Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC), Dubai-based ENOC, and several international giants such as Schlumberger and Halliburton, which offer services across the region.These companies provide a wide range of job opportunities, whether in field operations, refineries, administration, or research centers. By having access to the official email addresses of oil companies in the UAE, job seekers can connect directly with human resources or recruitment departments, speeding up the job search process and increasing their chances of landing an interview.List of Major Oil Companies in the UAE and Their Official Email Addresses1️⃣ Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC)Email: adnoc@adnoc.comWebsite: www.adnoc.aeADNOC is one of the largest national oil companies globally, managing exploration, refining, and distribution operations in Abu Dhabi.2️⃣ Emirates National Oil Company (ENOC)Email: ahmed.alaa@enoc.comWebsite: www.enoc.comENOC is a government-owned company engaged in oil, gas, and energy services with a strong presence in Dubai and the northern Emirates.3️⃣ Emarat (Emirates General Petroleum Corporation)Email: info@emarat.aeWebsite: www.emarat.aeEmarat focuses on fuel distribution and operates a network of service stations across Dubai and the northern regions.4️⃣ Abu Dhabi Gas Industries Limited (GASCO)Email: info@gasco.aeWebsite: www.gasco.aeGASCO specializes in natural gas processing and transportation.5️⃣ Abu Dhabi Oil Refining Company (Takreer)Email: publicrelations@takreer.comWebsite: www.takreer.comTak

The UAE job market in 2025 is showing strong growth, with around 69% of employers planning to hire, particularly in tech, healthcare, finance, and tourism. As the economy expands, roles in AI, cybersecurity, nursing, and regulatory finance are in high demand, with competitive salaries and opportunities for advancement. A shift toward skills-based hiring is reshaping recruitment, and nearly 73% of professionals are open to job changes, driven by a desire for better benefits and career growth. Trump-Era Tariffs 2.0: Why Dubai Could Be the Biggest Winner!---------------------------------------------------------------------In 2024, the total bilateral trade between the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and the United States reached $34.4 billion, marking a significant increase from previous years. This trade volume comprised $26.9 billion in U.S. exports to the UAE and $7.5 billion in imports from the UAE, resulting in a $19.5 billion trade surplus for the U.S.—its fourth-largest globally.With the potential return of Trump-era tariffs under a “Trump 2.0” administration, the UAE—particularly Dubai—is poised to benefit significantly compared to much of the rest of the world, especially China. As global manufacturers and exporters seek alternative trade routes to bypass high tariffs, Dubai is emerging as a strategic export and re-export hub for Chinese-manufactured goods destined for the U.S. market.This shift positions Dubai not just as a logistics gateway, but as a key trading intermediary between China and the United States, unlocking a new phase of trade growth. In the coming months, this dynamic is expected to fuel unprecedented increases in exports from the UAE to the U.S., as well as reciprocal trade flows.The ripple effects of this transformation will be profound—particularly for Dubai’s real estate sector. The demand for commercial infrastructure, including warehouses, logistics parks, and office spaces, is expected to surge. Simultaneously, the residential market is likely to experience heightened demand, driven by business expansion, workforce inflow, and investor interest. Together, these trends are set to reinforce Dubai’s position as a global trading and real estate hotspot.
